p: Estimates of μ, the dependence of a location’s susceptibility on its population size ranged from ~0.1–0.35, with a median value of 0.28 ( Table 3), indicating that more populated locations are at relatively higher risk for influenza transmission ( Fig 6). Parameter estimates for external seeding, ρ, varied several orders of magnitude between seasons, from ~0 in the 2005/2006 season to 0.98 in the 2004/2005 season. External seeding was weaker in seasons with particularly radial patterns in epidemic onsets—2002/2003, 2003/2004, 2005/2006. The large heterogeneity in estimates of ρ across seasons highlights the variable nature of long-distance transmission events in seeding epidemics during the seasons studied.
